data.text: Hi , welcome to india im a long distance cyclist in india who cycles just for fun and seeing my country , now for almost 25 years.. self supported , meaning carrying our own luggage on cycle ( which is not quite common in india) . im from Mumbai .. yes My country is a very safe country for women and guys too... and super friendly and very cheap to travel on cycle ..... warm showers and pitching tents is not very popular here so try to avoid it . I had a fellow female cyclist who traveled self supported the complete Uttarakhand state on her own and yes she did it in a very exciting manner ... , you can get in touch with her to get her experience the best route for westerners would be - Mumbai to Goa coastal route .. a tough route with ascends and descends... but a super beautiful route with a great essence of the Indian coastal culture ... and some amazing food which suits most of the westerners.... My friends and me are planning to do it this year end - the mumbai to Goa coastal route, do share ur plan - India is an amazing country with amazing people, amazing culture , amazing food and amazing natural beauty which u can't find it anywhere .... all the best

data.text: Embrace the chaos‚Ä¶ You shouldn‚Äôt have any issues camping at Hindu and Buddhist temples. Also, Gurdwaras are another option, as the Sikhs were the most hospitable in my experience. Make sure and leave some monetary donations at these places. Locals will always at least try to help out if you are in a place without accommodations. Just ask around, there are many who speak English. Start with plenty of small crisp bills. Travel with some Cipro and Metronidazole as backup for Delhi Belly. data.text: I can give you pages of advice. How long is your tour and where are you going? How much research have you done already. IT would be better if you could think of some specific questions. I dont want to spend all day on my answer. But here's a few tips. Don't wear lycra. Cover yourself up a bit. Beware of men who approach you to offer you help. Be cautiously friendly rather than aggressively rude when dismissing them, but don't just follow them blindly up any old alley. Try to stay humble always. People in india are often struggle for survival. They dont have welfare. Its usually money they want, not to rape you but you need to be cautious, especially being younger. Old people do get more respect. When you need help, you choose who to ask. Ride on small roads, not big highways. The guesthouses in remote small non-tourist towns can be pretty awful. Just be ready for that meanwhile. Never tell anyone how much your bike cost, or how much anything cost. If you do have to say something, keep the price low. You will have to put up with a great deal of repetitve enquiries and greetings. Dont get impatient or rude with it. Take a rickshaw ride in old delhi.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: You dont need to camp anywhere and i would avoid it if i were you. I mean i have done it once or twice but it is a risky thing to do in india because in most places, except up in the high himalaya, the population is too great and you will be seen. People will come and bother you. It is different for indians , especially guys riding htrough their own country. YOu need to be a bit more circumspect than indian guys, and couples and old women like me. You dont need to be frightened, you just need to be careful. Always take your valuables with you. Always keep your money and valuables on your body in a money belt under your clothes. If you ever want to return any hospitality favours, fruit is a nice gift because often they dont seem to eat much fruit and its not as cheap as vegetables.

data.text: Most of the locals speak a fairly understandable version of the English language, so there are almost no communication problems. For a "yes" answer they rock their heads left-right-left. Rock, not shake like we do for a "no". The "no" answer does not seem to exist. "Yes" often means "no", so asking questions without an option of choice is useless. For example: ‚Äî"Excuse me, does this road lead to Curchorem?" ‚Äî"Yes, yes, sir."‚Äîrocking his head side to side. but it clearly doesn't. So the only effective way of asking for directions is: "Excuse me, WHERE is the road to Curchorem?" (For this particular issue of asking directions, the wisest choice is to have a GPS navigator like I did. Or the "Yes yes sir" answers will lead you straight to the middle of nowhere.) If an Indian absolutely has to say no, he will start humming "ummmm" or "hmmmm" and have a desperate look on his face. Then you know it's a "NO".

data.text: Hi Maria, First of all welcome to India. India is a beautiful large country with all possible kind of terrain and landscape you can imagine that keeps changing in every few hundred kilometers. There's a saying that goes 'one doesn't need to travel entire world if the person has seen every part of india' As a full time tourer from India these would be my pieces of advice to start with. 1. Research well and decide your region and exactly what you want out of the trip. Dessert, forest, low hill, high altitude, coastal, cultural, landscape, rural everything you can find here depending upon your choices and tastes. (Route will come later into scenes. As in usual cases, you'd probably be modifying it many times on your journey.) 2. Whichever region you are choosing, get an elaborate idea about different routes of it. You can use couchsurfing, warmshower, many reliable cycle and travel fb groups(not all of them) to find travelers from different region to help you on this. Whichever route you are taking, plan it well in terms of distance and elevation and most importantly road condition that a gps map can't capture. 3. Plan your night stay well in advance depending upon your comfort level. Stelth camping is not the idea in India. Your options being... A.Make an online booking from a reliable website for the evening, B. Find a host C. Find a homestay or budget accommodation offline on the spot. E. Find a 'Gurudwara', Sikh place of worship, they consider it a virtue to give shelter to stranger E. Self camping. If you choose the last option make sure you are doing it 1. In the light. 2. Choose your campsite before dark 3. Do it near some human settlement/private property/police station/gas station/family with women and children etc. 4. Use your 6th sense. 4. To start bikepacking in India as a solo white female biker, start with the Himalayas or North-East India which resembles more with the South-East Asia. Women's safety is the last worry in these two part. Most of the South India is also completely safe for women traveller. 5.AVOID OR DO NOT TRAVEL WITHOUT A PEPPER SPRAY IN NORTH, CENTRAL INDIA like HARYANA, U.P, PUNJAB, DELHI etc. If you are alone and don't know what you are doing. 6. Keep you plans off the social media. Make sure it's not well advertised on the social media well in advance. You never know where the stalkers are. 7. Don't listen to advices from people/male/non-travellers who haven't toured well in their life or in India. The world is not really as bad as it seems from home or from the media. The list is not comprehensive,but as much as I can remember at the moment. It'd help to assist you if I know how much work you have done already. If you need any sort of assistance or guidance regarding bicycle touring in anywhere of India, you are most welcome to leave a message. P.S: These are some popular mountain circuit you can check out or combine to start from. Which are full of adventure and treacherous regions. 1. Spiti tribal circuit. (Shimla - Kaza - Manali) 2. Manali -Leh route. 3. Bir - Dharamshala - kashmir -leh - manali Etc

data.text: sure happy to - but i have never cycled in india. Can provide generic suggestions. Route and time is very important. Now the actual cycling - as far as i know there are no cycling routes - like the way you find in uk either within the city or intercity. Pitching a tent somewhere secluded on the way - i wouldnt recommend. Possibly you are thinking what scared chicken - but i would put personal safety first.
